text: The Expression Pattern of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Suggests a Role in Definitive Erythropoiesis

The observation that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice ectopically express <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in liver , where definitive erythroid cells mature , suggests that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is an important regulator in definitive erythropoiesis .
To determine the temporal and spatial expression pattern of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , Northern blot and in situ hybridization assays were employed .

As shown in Figure 6A , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is detectable by Northern blot beginning at 10.5 dpc , coincident with the temporal onset of definitive erythropoiesis in the liver .

Furthermore , in situ hybridization shows that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is highly transcribed in 12.5-dpc liver , but not in yolk sac blood islands at 7.5 dpc ( Figure 6B ) .
Therefore , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is temporally and spatially coincident with definitive , but not primitive , erythropoiesis .

These data , taken together with the observation that <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is highly expressed in the liver cells of 14.5-dpc p100H mutant mice ( Figure 5 ) , demonstrate that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions in definitive erythropoiesis .
